A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In the course of her training, the girl meets a charming aristocrat who offers to fix the race for an exorbitant price. The girl decides to accept the offer in order to finance the horse and her friends. But things go wrong.

Latter Days is a very, VERY independent movie. And compared to many of today's more modern films, it's lacking on many parts. The shooting budget was very cheap and the acting is rather stifled by the intense Christian messages scattered throughout the film. The sets are looking more like a low-budget TV show rather than a decent romantic comedy one would expect. But the story itself was very good and compelling. I guess that's why I expected more of the film.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Centered on Miyazawa’s own life, this film depicts his adolescence through the evil schemes of the local agriculture cooperative and the ideological rule enforced by the military-backed government of those days.
The ruling class of Japanese society held discordant views on weakness, sins, business ethics, and environmental salvation than Miyazawa.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form a posse to destroy the cat, and the cat has to ask a local woman, who loves cats (Kelli Williams) to help. With Frances Bay, Liane Curtis, Katharine Isabelle, Karen Austin, Richard Yniguez; directed by Rachel Talalay.
